title: Quarto Qrew
text:
This is a website for the Penn State Quarto Qrew.
We are a group of Penn Staters who are learning more about how Quarto can help us create more open, transparent, and reproducible research.

title: Goals
text: This page describes the goals of the Quarto Qrew.

title: Goals
text:
1 Individual goals

How Quarto websites and books compare to bookdown. Rick.

How do I change the default output directory to docs/ for use with GitHub pages? Rick.

Should Rick migrate PSYCH 490 course for Fall 2023 to Quarto? Rick.

How would Rick combine a Quarto-based syllabus with revealJS-based slides?

Should Rick keep using Quarto within RStudio or move to VSCode?

title: Goals
text:
2 Group goals

Should we migrate the Open Science Bootcamp 2023 site to Quarto? Rick.
What should a workshop on R Markdown/RStudio/Quarto for the Bootcamp look like? Rick.

title: How-to
text:
From the terminal, execute the following:
quarto render
Here are more tips about rendering: https://quarto.org/docs/computations/caching.html#rendering.

title: How-to
text:
2 Change default output directory
GitHub Pages prefers that website outputs live in the project’s root directory or in docs/.
We need to change the default output as follows. Edit the _quarto.yml file:
project:
  type: website
  render:
    - index.qmd
    - goals.qmd
    - how_to.qmd
  output-dir: docs






Note



We need to create docs/ before rendering the site, of course. We’ll leave _site/ in place since it is the default for output-dir.


The following resource provides more information: https://quarto.org/docs/reference/projects/core.html

title: How-to
section: 3 Set-up GitHub pages to render site
text:
3 Set-up GitHub pages to render site
If we have rendered the website to docs/ then GitHub Pages will automatically build our site when we commit to the master branch.
Here is a screenshot of the the repository settings that make this possible.



GitHub Pages settings
